>>6461269
Lol, no. I know people with Aphantasia that literally cannot visualize in their mind at all. I know artists whom like Frank Frazetta, have a early life history of either gymnastics/ballet/sports and they ''feel'' gesture and motion when sketching, others thatn can visualize like they have a 3D engine in their heads (Like Sam Nielson). Others see lines in perspective like Kim.
There are artists that have both skills, and other strange ones that don't get communicated because explaining qualia to other people is very abstract and complicated without personal experience.
Imagination is a ''skill'' highly limited by how your brain is built, and its also not a requirement to all professions in art. Illustrators don't need much imagination, in fact, being distracted by mental phantasmagoria is more suited to concept artists, where there less of a need to attention to detail and organization skills, and more of a requirement for abstract thinking and conceptualization.

There is not a single thing in this life, in terms of human capacity that is not limited by the flesh it comes from. Skills are not ethereal things that exist in the void, they are byproduct of the systems they come from. This is why, if you get brain damage, you loss abilities and skills, dude.

>>6445520
Nice, colors look good. One thing I'll say though is that because the shapes aren't totally accurate, some of the magic of the light source is lost. E.G.: the match flame in the ref is sitting in his cupped hand, and the light coming through the fingers emphasizes this. Your flame is about the same distance from the cigarette, but the hand is further away, so it doesn't quite sell the illusion of the skin glowing in the same way - it looks sort of like there's a second, invisible flame further towards his palm. This is hugely nitpicking though, thanks for posting.

Shit happens and all you can do is move forward. I spent my entire teens + early adulthood symbol drawing with little to no actual guidance because I didn't know how/where to learn properly. But I'm doing studies *now* and feel better than ever whenever I see my small improvements.

That said fuck social media. Just post your work and move on (and you don't even really have to post your work anyways. Unless you're trying to make a career out of it your art should just be for you). In a few years from now you'll have an archive of all your progress and it won't feel so meaningless.

paper artists use is more expensive to produce because, assuming you got something good, it will take pencil, charcoal, ink (as in dip pen), marker, watercolor and not shit the bed while also not ageing horrendously.

>>6461119
personally, get a2 news print, 500 sheets for about 15-20$, get way to cut the paper into a4 size, or a3, and get an at home binding kit, it should be fairly cheap, and get a 1/16th or 1/8 inch thick piece of plywood and put that on the back and finally get some sandpaper or sanding block along with I think a polycarbonate liquid top

sand the plywood smooth, shouldn't be too hard, treat the top so its smooth and protected, put the paper on it at whatever size you choose, and cut it out, then bind it as a backing to the thing. you not effectively have a sketchbook with shitty paper (still great paper for practice) that you can never delude yourself into thinking is something that will last, its always just something to practice on. you COULD get an a2 clipboard, but i'm assuming if you need a sketchbook, you need it to be more compact.

>>6457022

I'd disagree. I think it can matter a lot.

They would need to somehow find a lot of the different socials I'm posting with (which have different usernames), with a lot of my work being posted to obscure enough places like 4chan (which is notoriously bad at making things easy to find through archives). I don't plan on posting a lot to mainstream social media, so it shouldn't be easy to google for.

Additionally it looks like; the more isolated and simple a concept, the easier it is to train against. For example an individual character surrounded by a blank background. So if I have a particular IP or story I want to be protective of, I'd focus on posting work that's difficult to train against like that. So mostly complex finished pieces, that have a lot of different things going on, lots of perspective etc. I genuinely think this would be a meaningful deterrent. They could maybe copy some of the style with these pieces, but not so easily the content.

Like the reason why the Sam Does Arts models are so effective, are because he'd draw the same thing over and over again in a similar way, with relatively simple backgrounds etc. Then he'd have a massive body of work easily accessible through one or two mainstream sites.

posts.com:
When I see people seethe about AI, I wonder if this is how tradcucks reacted to the rise of digital art. Including the whole "muh soul" stuff.
AI is a tool. It's not supposed to be self-sufficient, just like a stabilizer in your drawing software of choice is not supposed to automatically solve all your lineart issues.
First of all, AI is the (potentially) ultimate referencing tool. For example, you wanna draw Makise Kurisu in Soejima's style, but you have no clue where to start. So just input a simple prompt, and bam, you have something like this. That is certainly good enough. The clothes are all wrong, but you're not an artist for nothing, you can fix that yourself. So copy it, add your own flavor, or try something else entirely, do whatever you want.
Second, AI is really good at inpainting. If you need a quick fix, or you don't like how something looks - consult the AI and see what it gives you, it takes seconds and maybe you'll find something inspiring.
Third, AI is really good at backgrounds. It paints huge complicated scenes of any variety in seconds. I don't even have to explain how that can be useful to someone who only draws anime girls and doesn't care about landscapes, but still needs landscapes in their art.

Work smarter, not harder. AI is a godsend for a hobbyist digicuck who simply wants to have fun drawing sexy girls, which is at least 80% of /ic/s population. Obviously, if you wanna take your art one step further and become a professional, AI won't help you much. But most of us are not doing this shit for a living, we just wanna draw cute anime girls in our free time.

posts.com: How do you guys gauge where something is in space when it has a vp off of the horizon line? Do you just draw a box and then what ever you need to draw you do so inside that box? It's a problem I've been having with legs and arms. Just can visualize them in space properly so the perspective on them always looks off. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458598
It's something that becomes intuition eventually. But it also doesn't have a really clear answer. For example, take the lowest corner of your cube in that piece and draw a straight line directly down to a point on your ground grid as if it was an object on a stand, like a miniature. Stopping anywhere on the grid changes how you perceive it in size and space. Your example could be a dolorean taking off from right next to that other car(box), or maybe a fly buzzing by really close to camera, or maybe it's really far away and really big, like a meteor. You can't tell because there are no other frames of reference. Our brains barely work as is, so expect to encounter weird ambiguous shit like this.

For choosing where and how to place these off-boxes, just draw an up line like the stand line from the point on the ground you want it to be above but again you're going to need to give other "perspective references" for it to be clear to the viewer.

>>6458887
Every object, regardless of orientation or vanishing points does technically share the horizon. Simple example is all things above the horizon are above the viewers view, things below below. All objects are gonna inherit that. So say all objects, including non-standard perspective objects, got blasted away directly perpendicular/forward away from you, they'd still go towards the horizon. In fact they'd be affected and follow "1 point perspective" rules even if they weren't 1-point objects like the tilted box >>6458831

>>6459745
NTA but I think he has a bit of a point.
If you're critiquing something, but draw yourself as a blank canvas with minimal emotion and then turn out to be wrong, you can still claim that you weren't that emotionally invested in the first place.
I cringe at the second comic more because there is more of a raw feeling to it and this childish resentment that artist feels over their "hard work" not being recognised which is both honest and likely embarrassing to think back on.
It's easier to err on the side of caution and pretend that you don't actually care that much, even if it's dishonest because you'd be leaving yourself vulnerable to be made fun of for having a strong emotional response to what others may deem trivial.
I disagree with that anon on one point though; I think it's perfectly understandable to do critique like this and I actually prefer it this way.
Nothing is as cringy as artists drawing themselves, pointing at the screen and whining about how unfair things are for them.
When you draw two characters chatting about the issue instead, it can still be cringy but not nearly to that degree and other people can still point out the errors without having to directly point their finger at the artist. I mean, they probably will anyway, but I still think it softens the blow.

Those parts just appear faster because they're larger areas of the same index. It's part of the old color cycling technique, used to control the speed of the animation in different parts of the image.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

Recommended watching:

Unrelated but what's up with Kevin Finch's pencil handle? It's taped?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6371401
You mean David Finch? The extra girth makes it easier to hold in general. You can hold it with a more relaxed grip or since it is soft, grip it tight without much strain on your hand. This helps to ease cramping from long sessions. It also makes it a bit easier to control of the tip of the pencil.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Insanely hard, took like an hour and a half, and an hour of that was just staring at it. Of course I got the first figure done before I realized it was gonna go off the page. So there are no corrections on this one, I did them after I took the picture because the page would be extremely cluttered. Still, I got more right on the bottom one than I thought I would. I think if you had to memorize one bridgman drawing perfectly, it should be this one. There are so many clues and shorthands about how bridgman constructs and thinks about the figure. I will be revisiting this one for sure.

I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

>>6431161
Oh it just looks sort of blocky like the Bridgman figures. You have the right idea in schematizing the block in but it needs to be a little more accurate. The values also look like they're done visually despite the planarization, so the dimensionality gets reduced. Speaking of values, this is a total pain but you should try to clean them up more. Literally sharpen your pencil to the finest point you can and fill in the little white dots on the paper, then go in with a kneaded eraser and pick out all the spots that are too dark. It'll be a huge pain in the ass but it will make your shadows especially look way flatter and give much more the illusion of depth, reality, and completeness.

posts.com:
I decided to do a study on my favorite artist, and one main thing I noticed and haven't been able to replicate is how "consistent" he is with ink thickness when doing certain areas.


I used >Krita's, Basic size / pressure pen, and my weights are so far off his.
After finishing my study I can only assume he is using a pen with no line weight? And changing it depending on what area he's working on? IE see the hair fringe vs the overall contour vs the hand thickness.
Is this the correct assumption?


I would gladly appreciate the input from anyone with a more trained eye then this 3 month beg (even about things not related to this that I should be aware of), that was the "main" crucial thing I noticed that I know I'm not doing currently.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6458487
>>6460834
thank you

>>6458968
that was a master study of painting. I like to mix things up by working from painting from time to time.

>>6460082
As a beginner, you should master the round brush with pen pressure if anything without it you're just sitting on a bunch of fancy tools you can't take advantage of. but dont just get one round brush with pen pressure and expect it to be good out the box, test out opacity and flow/ brush density and other round brushes till you find something that really feels natural in your hand ( a good brush will feel like butter and you will be able to blend without using airbrush/ blend tools)

to start I recommend these simple brushes it's what i used when i started and they got me used to rendering and i still use 'round' when rendering.

https://www.ctrlpaint.com/brushes

Ctrlaltpaint is a good site to teach you how to render as well, give it a look.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458068
>dials
1 for zooming in/out, that when pressed, will return to 100% zoom
1 for rotating canvas, that when pressed, will flip the canvas
1 for brush size, that when pressed, will toggle between your selected tool and eraser

>buttons
1 for undo
1 for redo
1 for selection tool
1 for free transform
1 for copy
1 for paste
1 for new layer
1 for eye dropper
1 for sketch brush
1 for blend tool

I'm sure there are tools I'm not thinking of that I'd like mapped as well, but a 12-15 key pad with 3 dials would be my ideal.

2 of those are mapped to my pen though, so 12 keys would be adequate I think.

>>6456820
I've talked about this in the past, and while it's true, it's not universal. It mostly applies to the most generic, simplistic anime styles of today. The style you'd see in a generic anime video game, in generic light novel art, or in your generic isekai anime or manga. Most vtubers also use that style.
Other styles with a bit more effort, personality and skill put into them usually don't suffer from this problem, because the artist understands the concept of volume, so his style usually adapts and takes on traits that make it look a bit more unique.

>>6457517
Lot to work on (though you have a base thats possible to build off of) but a quick one that I think would give you some gains: Id suggest not using thick lines everywhere. Using a thick line on only one side of a form can suggest light coming from the opposite side. More tips in picrel. Even just using thinner lines without worriying about weight will look less flat. Thick lines flatten the work if not used properly. I personally used to use them to cover up my bad, scratchy lines.

I'd like to thank everybody for the critique/comments, but I'm on mobile, so addressing everybody specifically is super hard, so forgive me here plz.

As for your advice on line weight, I specifically used heavy lines to denote limbs, so that when they are above something else, they don't get lost in the details, cuz I've had that happen before, and I know that my demon guy isn't actually very detailed, it's just criss-cross lines for shadow weight, I still felt like those lines could eat up the distinction between limbs. Especially since this guy's prominent trait is having six arms lol.
But I understand what your getting at, as I was about to start experimenting with the white glow/aura/outline I've seen used to do this as well.

And to other guy that said it could use more detail, that notebook is smaller than normal, it's like half, so not much room for details due to medium. But also, there wouldn't be much more detail anyways, as at that point I feel it would drown out the entire piece, and begin to detract from it. The demons initial design was to be skinless AS WELL AS all of the dramatic criss-cross shadows, but it just melded together and became scratch, so I ditched the gore-y aspect and stick to the dramatic shadows (see below).

Other other guy that said better/dynamic poses; yes, I know I've been needing to work on this, as my comfort zone is more for showcasing the character design, rather than telling a visual story, but also, in this case, part of the demons motif/design principle is "dramatic", hence the curtain wings, as well as the six arms to do more acting.

>>6459185
you don't need to worry about that, you will eventually develop your own style as you expand your taste. Your art is almost always just a combination of all your influences, until you get to a level where you naturally start creating your own shorthands. Just make sure you ONLY learn from people who you want to draw like. I learned to hatch from studying R Crumb, and now that I'm good at hatching I realized that all of my lines are very loose which I'm having to unlearn.

fundamentals are Perspective, Anatomy, Value, Color, Environments, and mastery of your medium (Inking technique, oil painting technique, etc)

I really am considering making a total beginners course because so many people here don't seem to understand how to learn or where to start. People scream LOOMIS but honestly I've only ever used loomis for proportions

Memory drawing: Look at the image, put the image away, draw it from memory. It's a brutal but effective way of learning, I estimate you'll see improvement at 5x speed. I wouldn't recommend it as a beginner necessarily, since you first gotta be able to draw a passable figure first. The memory thing is just forcing you to recall from your visual library more effectively.

As a beginner, just copy Bridgman, and do your life drawing

>>6450083
>>6450221
Hi Bridgman-san, you're doing fine, I've been posting along with you in /msg/ this past year. Attached is a page from when I was in the feet section, the memory drawing and corrections are both there, so it's great we both had the idea of correcting the drawing after the fact. The chapter I struggled the most on was the beginning chapter, with all the full figures, but once you start getting into the body parts it goes a lot quicker.

My end goal was to get my drawing EXACTLY like how Bridgman had it, but of course I often fell short. In the beginning, I would stare at the drawing for 15-20 minutes, drawing it in my head over and over again, then I would bang out the sketch really quickly, to not lose any information. When I was doing the full figures in the first chapter, I could only do 1-2 drawings at a time before my brain went caput, but it really does get a lot easier after that.

My one criticism of your process is to use pencil, and then ink on top. imo it's important to give yourself the room to make mistakes. Even all my ballpoint pen sketches I did from manga in /msg/, I used pencil underneath.

About me taking only 1 month to go through Bridgman versus how long you've been doing it, I just chalk that up to the fact that I already had several years of drawing experience before doing Bridgman, so I could do my studies very quickly, and i did it for 8 hours a day, like a maniac. For you, don't worry about how long you're taking, 1-2 hrs a day is plenty to progress. I think you're doing it right, I might've rushed Bridgman, to my own detriment.

Anyways, do your 30 mins of gestures, and your Bridgman, and you'll do fine. However, Bridgman isn't the end, even after finishing it I still feel inadequate. You really will have to study for the rest of your life.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6453917
the head section isn't bad, you have to know what his drawings are shorthand for. drawing as many heads in cubes as you can showing the planes is tremendous practice for drawing in perspective. he would commonly recommend that as a warmup for that at the art students league.

a lot of the diagrams are modeled after how master painters in the 1800s and before would think about anatomy. the only one i don't care for in your picture is the child but that's making a point of what all the bumps are that cause plane changes on a face which you might not recognize as being indicative of the anatomy.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6448467
Rushed this one out, sorry, but essentially it boils down to two things, anon. Contrast, and grouping. Your values/shadows essentially are the result of form and light. Right now you're adding unnecessary detail in areas that should be low detail, like the belly. You're leaving small light spots that attract our attention where it shouldn't be (if the tummy should be the highlight you'd need a different composition.)

When you think about values and light you should think of the painting as a whole. Unless it's concept art, a middle range value lile the one you picked for your painting is a pretty bad place to start, because already the whole composition is pretty much in the same value range. Especially early you shouldn't be afraid of really pushing the value range, somdare to go much darker and much lighter.

Keep your light sourse in mind. And what the light itself /is/. Different types of light will cause different shadows to be created. Harsh sunlight, for example, causes fairly dark but warm coloured shadows and might cause light to bounce off large surfaces. So a chin, which is pointing downwards but juts out might cast a lighter shadow than the nect area, as light is being reflected off of the ground. This is why thinking of form is also very important.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455701

I post in random discord servers, ones not related to art at all. The smaller and more social the better. I use telegram too. Engage as much as possible and try and get people to interact with you as a person first as the highest priority and then as an artist as a close second.

My feeling is if you put your shit in the kind of places where people can find furry art, they're probably already internet literate and discerning about their tastes and art standards, so if they're presented with the cost of your art compared to someone else's which is identical but cheaper they're 95% gonna choose the cheaper option, the other 5 % are going to choose you only if there's something really unique about your product. The internet is really fucking wide and anyone who's been there knows nothing is unique there.

My goal was to collect ten geese that shit out gold eggs. The best I ever got was one patron, I got real depressed drawing cocks for them hours and hours each day. But if you go the internet version of door knocking instead of the flyer drop, you have a better chance of finding patrons who will pay you what they think you're worth, not what you lowball.

Best I was turning was a small handful of 100 USD dollars per commish, but they each took me probs a months and a half to complete, not because they were hard, but because I got so depressed with it and procrastinated really hard.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

Read the sticky

>>6460782
>>6460396
I think people see 'read the sticky' and they get in this /fit/ mindset, that 'right, I'm making a big life change, I need to do X and Y and Z right now all day no cheats', because I think, (which shows you how much I know about that too lol) that if you stay at a certain weight your gains plateau and your muscles don't grow.

Art isn't a muscle. At least not in that regard. It's a skill that you learn because it is enjoyable to learn. Yes you don't want to rest on your laurels, YES, you want to improve, but nobody said you needed to speedrun Loomis, there's no Summoning Salt music intro for /ic/ tourneyfag coming on going 'I got gud in 36.7 seconds, and...' and like you gotta memorize the blook skip.

The value has to be internal on drawing, you gotta practice, but you gotta also draw what you want to draw. I'm drawing fucking gay OCs for a /co/ show, I have no interest in portraits or still lives, I want to draw cartoons that reflect the wacky adventures I write about in my stories. I'm not even set up, this is my digital art's extension right now. Windows 11 Paint, with my right hand that I don't even draw with in not good conditions. This is as far from practice as I can get, /ic/ should rightfully ban my ass for even posting it here on /beg/, to attempt to improve it would be a sisyphean waste of energy, but it was FUN. People get into this 'oh I gotta have the right stuff/it's gotta be a certain perfect level/I'm cringe if I'm not ready' and yeah for the autistic minmax response of an /ic/ thread, sure, respect the board culture, we ARE the Village Green Preservation Society and all but

Dudde, DRAW what you WANT to DRAW, it's healthy. Hell, with the practice you have, you can draw the 'what you want to draw' better. Think about how it can improve too, reflect on your fun art. But have FUN, for God's sake. Art is a time-consuming, energy intense, and expensive hobby. What the fuck are we even doing here, if we're not having fun with it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460862
I believe it's important, but the way they are explained for design in youtube and social media is catered specially for modern cartoons and animation where simplicity reigns.
I prefer the approach of Marcos Mateu in Framed Ink, in which he explains the character has to have a distinct silhouette if it's going to change outfits on a regular basis. This silhouette can be composed of complex and unique forms, not just circles boxes and triangles with 'S' curves written all over the place.
I'd say it's a meme just because the modern design philosophy regarding it seems to be really superficial and basic, it'd take a talented and skilled designer to create something which is unique, has clear shapes but remains subtle, meaning it doesn't take the viewer out of the immersion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There are a lot of factors in how a design can be received by a viewer. Shape design is one factor. The place where a character is first encountered is another. These factors combine and form a complex reality. The meme is putting a formula on how a character must look or ought to look. If the viewer is to learn about a character, if they behave like a villain the character will appear villain-like to them no matter what their visual appearance is. It's not an issue if they appeared like a villain at first unless that was something you wished to be the case (in which case, go ahead and make your commonplace villain design using shape design memes. Viewers have seen enough movies to put together the patterns).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Why There Are No Longer Masterpieces
posts.com:
If Bernini had lived today, he would have shown an interest in art at a young age. But, as a child, he would have received no education in art beyond a class per week (or every other week, alternating with music). He would not have had the possibility of joining a guild or workshop, and could not have devoted more than a few hours on weekends to drawing on lined notebook paper and cheap sketchbooks from birthday gifts, because he needed to go to school and learn skills that will allow him to make money as an adult. If he is lucky, the birthday gifts also include a book of art history, but for the most part, his visual diet consists of cartoons and photographs. Only a few of these images are even attempting to be “high art”.

He sees Miyazaki films and feel something profound, which he interprets as a love for anime. His friends mock him for it. He has never entered a cathedral or a gallery and only twice entered an art museum by the time he is 10 years old. Suppose he sets himself right by the end of adolescence – he picked through Wikipedia and Instagram and Pinterest and 4chan and learned that good art exists, and a little bare bones information about how it is made. Suppose he devotes all free time to drawing (against his parents’ better judgement) and develops a portfolio decent enough to be admitted into an atelier.

(will continue)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457560
But the tuition is too high for a job that will never pay out. This is the first real blow to his dreams, the first wake up call. His parents remind them that his online friends who “drop likes” on his Deviantart posts are not paying customers (at least not for anything more than $5 prints) and break the news to him that his work is not truly remarkable. It’s undeniable – his penwork is untrained and his brushwork is nonexistent, because of course, he’s had no formal help and never chose a particular method to master, always grabbing a bit of this technique and a bit of that from a thousand online sources. He is suicidal for a few weeks (or years) but is sent to CBT therapists who teach him to manage emotions and push forward. Armed with Prozac but with a sense of foreboding still clinging to him, he goes to a regular college (it hardly matters anymore whether it is a state school, Ivy League, or community college) so that he will at least have the certifications necessary to work and hopefully go back to the atelier someday. Bernini chooses to major in Business with a minor in Fine Art, or Graphic Design with a minor in Art History. It’s the best he can do.

(will continue)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457564
He puts aside artistic endeavors for the next few years, practicing only at an interval of months because the heavy hours needed to save up for an education do not leave time for serious creative work. At around age 30, finally, he finds himself at the atelier of his dreams. It was against his better judgement yet again. He is already married and considering children, and has had to uproot his life and halt his career in order to take off even a year. He will certainly have to return to paying work when this year is over. What kind of art can he possibly produce, even supposing he catches up for his lack of technical training in early life? It will be dull at best, focused on the misery and drudgery of his lived experience and his sense of inadequacy in comparison to past artists who had greater advantages. Or perhaps he will focus on his greatest lived experience - sex with his wife.

This is why the masterpiece hardly exists. When it exists, it is stained with bitterness about the state of the world, with romanticization of past golden ages when art was respected (often straying a little too close to the fascism which also occupied those eras), and with ironic self-referentialism about its own absurdity. It apologizes for itself – or fails to do so and becomes “cringe.”

Although you would like to think you would have a chance in an older time, you would most likely be even more gatekept from art as self-teaching was not as easy and art education was much more exclusive. It's not about living today or back then, it's about whether you're poor or not. Being poor back then would've been way worse and you likely wouldn't be able to even pursue or enjoy art as a hobby like you do today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Even if you might be good at it, it may still not be a fit because you don't like it. For example I'm great at the physical and mental aspects of my work, but there's so much bureaucratic paperwork horseshit associated that it sucks all joy I might have from it.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a tough balance. In order to get better at what you want, you need to practice what you want. But you also need to develop a better understanding of art in general to get better at what you want, and a lot of how this is balanced will depend on the person. Some people seem to be able to go "hey, I want to draw cartoons," and just shit out garbage drawings left and right of whatever they want to draw, and in five years they're pro quality. Then you also have the people who go "hey, I want to draw cartoons," and they too shit out drawings left and right of whatever they want to draw, and in ten years they're still cluttering up their DeviantArt gallery with drawings that look maybe just a little bit better than what they started with.
Everybody should do studies, but some people are just better wired for learning by doing than others - what they learn intuitively through repetition and experimentation, others will require knock-them-over-the-head direct studies and explanations to have any hope of incorporating it into their normal work.

Even outside of art, I'm sure most people had one or two subjects in school that they just "got," where they'd read the lesson and after attempting a couple practice problems be able to handily complete any relevant assignment, while their classmates would struggle with homework, consulting study aids, and re-reading notes to develop even a passing comprehension (or more likely rote memorization serving as a rudimentary understanding) of the material.

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

>>6459528
The tapered strokes in the clothing creases make me think he's using pressure for size
There's a hotkey to enable/disable it in photoshop but even without that you can keep the line weight consistent if your pressure control is good enough.
Also, I don't think it's uncommon to go back and fine tune line weight throughout after the initial drawing, using restating/vector tools/etc. IIRC DAB tells you to do something like this for thickening the outer boundaries. What you see might be multiple passes.

>>6459528
nice, play with the brush settings try reducing the flow of the ink-3 gpen to 34%. on preassure control I think a S curve is the best in responsiveness vs dynamic range ( ink-3 gpen already has a nice s curve on size pressure). another thing to consider is hardware e.g. wacom pro pen 2 is way more dynamic range than say wacom 4k pen this allows to control better the line weight (this is the main reason people say pro nibs are eaten away faster). and the most important experience are you sure there are no double passes or erasing on the og?

ok then we can rule hardware sensitivity out (remember its not really important it only matters on how you set up your tools).
Then I suggest to play around with technics, leave that alone and practice a little of contour lines, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97-LDiSaam4 after some practice come back to the gyaru and redo her.
A tip for overlapping lines, create a tmp layer now use big (huge) gesture for the new line, erase until both lines seamless join together (no bumps) then merge down. and the bigger the canvas the better.

>>6427259
>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

posts.com:
Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

/mmg/ - Manga Making General:
>>>/ic/mmg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6443881
>read pen & ink by guptill, it's literally what mangakas study
>take a few pieces of lineart from an artist you like and try to do a study from like where you imitate the style of rendering on a more simplistic object
>do a rough sketch and then try different line techniques on another layer, then try drawing another version w/o the underdrawing
what helped me a lot was taking a month where i only drew w/ the binary brush & eraser on one layer while trying to limit undos (ideally none at all) the drawings sucked compared to my normal work & were way harder at first but i learned an absolute shitton and became way more confident about working without crutches

In geometry a line is 1 dimensional, in art they're thin two dimensional shapes.
Don't treat them like a 1 dimensional boundary that you outline things with to make a drawing. Treat them like a shape that needs to be drawn, because they are the drawing.

>any tips?

one thing they taught us in high school by some lecturer who was visiting was to do this "duck method" you basically grab your pencil in a clasp like a duck bill almost, close one eye, pull it up to your open eye and measure the angle by lining up the pencil with the line you want, then you just hold the angle and use another pencil in your other hand to mark the angle on your paper. you can even go back and double check you got your measurement right, i do this alot and it really helps.

>>6460895
You did really well.

I'd use orange/brown and purple predominately in your piece. Her skin tone is brown so a slightly more orange hue for the pumpkin and other things would work well here while keeping your the number of colors in the piece low.

The key is to use as few colors as possible to really sell this stuff.
Look up color gamuts, james gurney explains this well.

That way you can use an ascent color to bring out points of interest like the yellow/green mixture for the eyes you did to make the eyes stands out as it goes against the orange/brown and purple. Make the contrast more jarring by making the orange and brown colors here closer. Saito naoki has some videos on color ascents.

I also wouldnt really make the bow red since it could clash with the other colors
Maybe make the bow orange but keep it distinct from her skin tone.
Also you can make the tear not clash by making it colorless. Not all water has to be blue.
Same with the eye glow, maybe make it more purplish instead of blue.

less is better

>>6458087
Don't copy, it becomes a type of crutch, which only limits your ability, whereas learning to do it yourself from scratch, even if your trying to recreate something else, sharpens your abilities and let's you do more.

Also, the flaws of the artist that your copying becomes your own, so instead of improving, your stagnating, or becoming worse.

Also also, work on fundamentals, like anatomy. Everything else gets undermined if the character has uneven arm lengths or something like that, but a strong base can only get better, so don't worry about shading or stuff like that right away, strengthen your anatomy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455543
Have you tried straight line technique?

When doing your under-drawing use thin straight lines. When doing the line work, that's when you curve it. It can help quite a lot with getting proper proportions and that sort of thing.

Also, try starting with one straight line for shoulder to shoulder, and another for the pelvis. These lines will always be at opposing angles. This really helps to get the angles of the gesture right from the start. If you want to go above on this, do a 3d square shape for the rib-cage (more starting from armpit area to bottom of the rib-cage). Then you do a similar 3d square for the pelvis. Know where the horizon line is. Generally you will see the bottom of the rib-cage box, and the top of the pelvis box.

posts.com:
>>6460630
I actualy am learning figure drawing that way. The thing is, you should break down the body into separate parts (head, ribcage, arms, fingers etc) and learn to draw them alone in perspective (create ortho views based on their proportions and rotate them in boxes). Then you learn how to compose each part into a figure (gesture drawing).

I heard about this method from Krenz, and am still learning it. It looks pretty hard at first, but personally its the only way that made sense for me. I find other methods too "feel the form" level of clarity

the artist problem is simple, ai is not able to create, it requires being fed info to generate art, said art is very... dubious harvested, no one consented to it.

while yes, artists steal and use reference, its far FAR different from how an ai does it to the point there will be a major lawsuit if its ever found commercially used without an artist to filter whats it makes.

then you have the legitimate fear that if it does get good enough, I personally don't think it will for a long LONG time (with ai, the baby steps are fast, but getting the kinks out, see hands or eating ramen, is going to take a long time where it never really looks like it improves) but if it does and it gives people what they want in less than 10 seconds for thumbnails and less than 30 minutes for a full piece (I am thinking a future where it generates a small image to save resources, and then dedicates resources to making a large image when the user ok's it) then there is a chance that the artist is dead for commission work, artists will only really be relevant for generating a style.

right now ai is just at a tool stage, its not at an end product one.

>>6455788

You will likely not get things right on one go you need to keep trying and iterating your character(s). It takes patience, as you keep drawing and iterating on them you will getbetter at drawing them and also will grow more close to them.

Hating on them right after can also come from your own insecurities. You felt like you have accomplished something yesterday by creating your OC and it felt good you, got a dopamine hit from seeing that you had something accomplished. But the next day is another day and you are not feeling the same dopamine hit, you expected to feel it again when you look at your character but you are not getting it. So you are disappointed and you overcompensate and start hating it for not getting what you felt yesterday. The satisfaction yesterday likely came from you getting your shit together and creating something. From the act of creating a thing not directly from the thing itself.

Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. VR chat did not exist when I was actively building in Second Life, from 2006-11. People could make real cash building stuff in it. I sold animated paintings and other strange things, but the lure was the creative outlet for me. You conjure basic shapes out of the air,morph them,link them up into larger objects,and insert scripts to make them do various tasks. My paintings were textures of the frames of GIFs laid out in a grid,and the script would display them in order,giving the illusion of animation.

I am part of their official history, in a small way. See the eye in the lower center of the pic? That archway was my contribution to Burning Life 2007,the Burning Man event. Here is a video of it...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450621
Ok, its different.
I used to draw 2D years ago, I always loved art. I was also working with 3D stuff. But a couple of years ago I really wanted to try sculpting my own characters and trying that route.

3D as other person said adds that extra dimension and, unless you are not going to rotate a single degree your camera, everything can go wrong with just small movement. Do you know how in 2D drawing you are always mirroring the image just in case theres something wrong you didnt see because your mind got used to it?
Well, in 3D you keep rotating the model, zooming in, seeing how that face looks in that angle, from behind, profile, activating the perspective, adjusting the fov...

And thats only the sculpting thing. Then theres the UV, rig, weight painting, texturing (painting), knowledge of many programs (well I dont use Blender), retopo, baking textures, lighting, camera setup, animating and other extra things in Unreal like adding particles, C++ programming, cloth physics, environmental design, props, etc etc.

Here is my latest scene. You'll say:
>why so much work for something you can just draw?
First of all, I love 3D, pushing me over and over, making me proud of my work. The practical/useful part is I'm able to use these sculpts for many other things, like interactive clothes, changing their hairs, lighting/shadows in real time, making some minigames with them or anything you can imagine

>>6450941
well lets see here.

a good sculpting engine will handle several million polies without issue, so there is no reason to retop unless you want to animate or make a low poly version for a game

modeling is not hard, but it can be a bit paint by numbers and not fun, especially when its small shit for a background. (protip, if the shit is small enough to never be a focal point, draw it in as a 2d plane and be done with it, think plants and shit going up a building in the background, its never going to be close up enough to be seen so why do it right?)

texturing isn't hard, there are litteral banks of free texture data, if you are to retarded to know how to use them then 3d is beyond you

you don't need to rig or weight paint unless you animate, rigging is so retardedly simple I was able to do it as a kid in the 90's much less re doing it a few years ago because I wanted to try something.

weight painting is again, not hard.

lighting is literally done for you unless you are too retarded to understand the fundamentals of lighting a shot (protip, room lighting, positional lighting and bounce lighting are needed in every room unless you are going for a specific look. look into irl lighting to help you)

you only animate if you want to animate, and at this point 3d, and every step to get to animateing is easier and faster than doing the animation traditionally even when you think the 3d artist is a 100% beginner, and the 2d animator is a veteran who knows what they are doing the 3d will churn something out faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6450840
>drawabox
No wonder drawing makes you feel like ass. I can't imagine doing that crap and I've been drawing for years. I don't know if it'll help but I'll lend you some of my advice. Pick your favorite artist you want to draw like and start copying their stuff. Not serious 1:1 studies, just make some shitty doodles with whatever looks cool to you. In my case I just copied Akira panels because I always loved it. I must've copied half the series at some point. After a while I began to understand how Otomo drew figures. I didn't realize then that I was basically just doing figure studies, just not with irl people. Some time later I got confident enough to learn from other artists I admired and got better at copying, then I actually went over the fundies books that everyone pushes on prebegs. I felt like I learned in reverse but there is no wrong way to learning as long as you're making progress. Another piece of advice is to grow some skin and learn to take and LISTEN to advice from your superiors and apply it. Don't assume you know better when someone tells you this shading is inconsistent or this fold doesn't make sense etc.

Point is, while art is practice and hard work, it doesn't mean you can't have fun. Like with working out, you can make fun out of activities.

>>6450706
I admit I was mad at first about AI because I felt like it was taking away my opportunity to make it as an artist, but the more I think about it:
>I never wanted to do commission work anyway, since drawing other people’s OCs seemed really boring to me, I’d rather draw my own characters
>I never wanted to draw “flavor of the month” characters, ie whatever Nintendo girl is popular right now, I just want to draw characters I like
>I never wanted to pay attention to numbers on social and obsessing over what stuff gets the most engagement, stressing over likes/retweets takes the joy out of drawing
Etc. Of course, I’d still do a lot of that stuff, just because I wanted to “make it” and not because I actually wanted to draw it. And even with doing that, the truth is the chances of “making it” were always infinitesimally low, so I’ve realized AI never took away my chance, I never had a chance in the first place.
Of course, that doesn’t mean I’m going to quit drawing, since I still enjoy drawing. It just means I can focus now on doing what I want to do, and drawing what I want to draw, and if I can get some income off of that then that’s nice, but I’m not going to go into it with the illusion that I can actually make a career off of it.
In a way, I feel like this is a healthier mentality to approach art anyway.

Starting to think making a crappy sketch, drawing with AI and then tracing it by hand and polish with low noise value to be a worthwhile method.

Also, photobashing results from diferent AI results into a single piece to provide some solid results, much better than what I initially hoped.

I don't mean I lack skills, just that mentally is much easier to trace and fix than do the whole drawing from scratch.

>>6456628
This tracing only works if you already know how to draw, and you just want to have a quicker base to draw on. You'd be generating 20-30-40 pics and you wont be getting the exact one you want. Your best bet is really to just cut out whichever parts that appears correct (see: you need to already know how to draw/ how the correct stuff looks like) and then stitching them together correctly.

For background, you can actually just paint over the shapes if its a clear shape without gradients and other effects like glow or translucency. But you dont want to be making obvious mistakes like a wall that is not connecting behind the subject like AI generated ones would.

Generate and then use them as-is with 'simple' fix? Not gonna work. With background it's so much of a mess to fix, you're better of drawing over it from sketch. And you're stuck with that generic AI artstyle as well.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6367918
Depends on the colors and obviously on the pigment, let's just say that even on artist grade gouache they're very liberal with their lightfastness grading. Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

>>6399981
G pen is good option if you don't like fineliner. Maru nibs is an option for thinner lines. Dip pen need a lot of practice and kinda messy at first. Stick with Japanese brands.
Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

>>6410284
Water and soap, try not to get acrylic stuck in the ferrule as that will permanently ruin the brush. >>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

>>6426165
For dry drawing media, I use a silver point. My favorite surface is fine Carrara marble dust that is mixed with Dutch lead white which has been ground in vinegar and washed, sometimes tinted with other pigments. For darker lines, some pumice or quartz. For the glue, I choose parchment size mixed with a solution of potash alum.
For the ink to use with natural quill, I take the shavings of red sandalwood or brazilwood and heat it gently in well water, which afterwards is mixed with gum arabic and a pinch of potash alum. I add a drop of clove oil as a preservative.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428703
I can't see any of those videos, only the thumbnails because I don't have an Instagram account, but it looks like he uses a fair bit of line weight.
Fineliners are alright and very straightforward for a beginner to use since they always have a single constant width but they won't get you natural line variation, you'll need to manually thicken the line by drawing over it. Their lines can feel very mechanical otherwise, which is only natural considering they're like a disposable version of technical drawing pens.
Fineliners don't shatter under your hand or anything, but they tend to be inconsistent and start having ink flow problems with time, requiring you to hold them very vertically to keep working. The problem is compounded if you happen to be heavy-handed, so if you think that might end up a problem it might be a good idea to pick up Uni-pins instead since they have very durable tips.
But Microns are perfectly well-loved pens as far as their type goes. If you're in for even and consistent lines it's what fineliners will give you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428739

ty anon, im still a little confused and looking for direction.

I just wanna try doing some manga style with dynamic line weight, whats a good starting point in terms of pens for learning anime/manga

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428775
Mangaka mainly use dip pens (pic rel), but they're difficult to control and can be a bit hard to find. Bristle brush pens and proper brushes have the most line variation and they're what's behind most of those 熱血 crazy-looking thick lines in drawings by animators like Umakoshi and Hayama. They're also very difficult to control. The difficulty can be a good thing if you want to challenge yourself and train your dexterity, but it could get frustrating for a beginner.
Felt tip brush pens are comparatively really easy to control and you can still get good line variety out of them. I've never used the Micron one but it's probably fine.
A lot of manga artists do use fineliners, but it's usually for details, hatching or speech bubbles. Maru nibs produce similarly thin lines, but they can thicken a bit if you press harder. You can still get super delicate lines out of a pen or brush if you're skilled enough, Akihito Yoshitomi does a lot of detailed machine drawings with dip pens on YouTube if you're interested in watching someone ink in real time.
That's not to say nobody ever inks mainly with fineliners, and I think they were common in shoujo manga in the 2000s. They're very popular with people who draw anime-style illustrations on social media and can be very convenient to work with. They eventually worm their way into a lot of people's workflows, so there's no harm getting some experience with them now if you want to. I think with inking it's definitely a matter of trying a lot of things and seeing what suits you.
Whatever you end up with, I hope you have fun, Anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6447254
Honestly go for the one that appeals most to you. If price is a big factor any medium works well with a limited palette of 6 or more colors. There are many ways to make a certain medium more expensive and cheap, which is why I would also consider oil. For example, oil paint covers huge areas easily with very little paint and there are inexpensive oil painting papers to paint on. Another example is if you compare gouache and watercolor, the gouache paint is a little bit more expensive, because you will finish it faster, but on the other hand, you don't need good paper for gouache. All of them have their difficulties and advantages, but if I would recommend an all rounder that's forgiving I would suggest oil even though it's not in your list. If this is not an option for you, I would choose gouache over acrylic, because it's forgiving in brush quality and maintanence and it's better for sketching and making smaller pieces. The emulsion is not as strong as with acrylic, which makes it easier to handle the paint on the brush and canvas. Go for watercolor only if you love watercolor or you going to have a bad time. Watercolor is an outlier and has some specific qualities that you only should put up with if you really want to go for the watercolor look and feel. I agree that it's inexpensive to get into though, but it benefits from higher quality paper. So all in all, I would suggest gouache if you don't want to consider oil, but personally I don't like the Himi gouache, it has a strange consistency and it has too many colors. Consider a high quality brand like W&N, Holbein, Schmincke, Graham, but getting a small limited palette of 5-7 colors plus a big tube of white. Get those air tight wet palettes that everyone uses for gouache nowadays (I use them too, they are great) and you are good to go with a couple of synthetic taklon brushes. While you need thick paper to prevent buckling, you don't need 100% cotton, gouache is fine on cheap, thicker paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
on the subject of least expensive medium
technically, it would be using dry pigments mixed with gum arabic or egg yolk.
egg tempera is cheaper if you take a bit of the yolk from when you cook with eggs. a whole yolk is too much waste.
gum arabic is cheaper when you consider a bag of the dry powder can last for years upon years.
extra expenses are that egg tempera should be done on stiff support that is covered with traditional gesso ground which can be intimidating for a lot of beginners. i have tricks for anyone who actually cares to use it. watercolor paper can be more expensive if you don't have access to scrap wood. but if you don't egg or gum paint, then you can try out other media with the pigments.
for both, kolinsky is considered the best which can be quite expensive. but great thing for either is that they are not hard on the brushes unlike how oil can be and especially acrylic, and brush clean up is easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455419
I'm not a Micron fan. I do like that they're readily available even in stores like Walmart in case you need an emergency art pen, but otherwise that's their only pro in my opinion.

I use both the reusable Copic pens and the disposable. The reusable ones are way more expensive up front but quickly pay for themselves, so I buy the pens I use the most in refillable form and everything else is disposable. Quality-wise, they're both pretty much the same so I wouldn't recommend shelling out for the refillable kind if you're just using them every once in a while or you (understandably) don't want to spend like $12 on a pen. The other type of pen I use is a G pen, which is both affordable and uses affordable dipping ink that last forever. My only complaint there is that it's not as convenient as the non-dip pens and also the ink takes a while to dry sometimes. I have never used Rapidographs.
