posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455421
1. Wear drawing gloves (or in my case, a sock). This is important so that your hand can glide; it makes a difference.
2. Flip canvas horizontal or rotate canvas for awkward drawing angles. Everybody has a natural angle they're better at drawing lines with.
3. Stabilizer. Crank that shit up so your lines are smooth even when drawing with your arm (drawing with the arm can sometimes cause wobbles). Use this to a second pass on your drawings since stabilizer can mess up the flow of sketching.
4. Too much pressure sensitivity on a brush can be a noob trap. Try using stiffer brush sensitivity until you've gotten control of that.
5. Practice re-inking manga (tracing but you're going for a high level of reproduction). Have a window open of the reference to refer to as well. Doing 3-4 of these with a high level of precision will teach you a lot.
6. Hopefully you have a medium-sized tablet; the small models are a bit cramped.
7. If you have a wacom model, go for the flex nibs. They're softer and so have a superior feel over the hard plastic nibs.
8. Have patience with yourself, there's a lot that goes into linework. I use only a screenless tablet and many people who do good linework also do. Understanding what your hands need to draw good lines is the first step.

Here's the pen if you want it, it's for clip studio: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1edmT5vRR_7IjscccuhAbDw3w5n8NtlLp/view?usp=sharing

>>6455421
My attempt, used hard round with no stabilizer on. Depending on what you're making, e.g black and white manga or lineart to colour in, you should take a different approach. I tried making lineart that could be considered relatively finished without adding colour.

Generally though, unless your lineart is what you want to focus on more than anything else, It's something that will improve pretty naturally as you get better. Most people who struggle with basic lineart don't have particularly good sketches to begin with.

For instance, a common issue with beginners that struggle with lineart is the use of really messy and loose sketches, which look ok at first, but are really hard to work with when explicit decisions have to be made on the placement of lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460526
With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

>>6460747
>what were the chances he'd be as good as AI?
This phrase misses a lot about art. Even if AI reaches technical proficiency at the fundamentals, that is not the only criteria for art. There are so many artists with quirky styles whose artistic identity would be lost if they plugged their art into AI. These styles won't develop if budding artists use AI as a crutch. There will likely be so much factory-produced looking shit in the next few years. Good news is that any art with a shred of humanity will stand out in the sea of shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460785
I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai. Sure, some of them were trying to learn it at some point but so were a lot of other people who never had the patience to actually become good at it and eventually ended up moving on to other things. Promting just happened to what this partucular group moved on to but I seriously doubt many of them would have become "proper" artists if not for ai. They'd more likely just be playing video games or shitposting on reddit instead.

In the end, comparing drawing to prompting is like comparing someone taking a photo of a landscape to someone making a painting of that same landscape. Sure, they might come up with results that look similar but the process in itself is so different that one person would most likely not enjoy what the other is doing and vice versa. Are there some people who like both painting and photography? Sure, just like some will combine the two into a single artwork but there are also plenty of people who only enjoy one of the two and there's nothing wrong with that. It's simply two different ways to produce an image.

Not saying this to defend ai by the way, I still think the way it was produced and marketed is shady as fuck and I'm all for regulations to stop these schizos from creating their AGI dystopia. But I also think saying "why would you prompt if you can just learn how to draw" is disingenuous in a way, since most of the current prompters likely would never have learned how to draw anyway, with or without the existence of ai

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460829
>I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai.
I was mainly referring to the img2img examples I've seen here and elsewhere where someone inputs a 'bad' drawing to get a more refined image. I can see this becoming a standard practice for insecure artists.
There are so many artists I admire (early comic strip artists, underground comics artists, outsider artists) where the beauty is in the idiosyncrasy. If they used this technology all the quirks would be ironed out into a boring sterility.
I do agree prompting serves a different impulse from drawing, but that doesn't mean artists won't feel pressured to use AI in their 'workflow.'

dual monitor, photoshop.

in photoshop you can put up a window that show your workspace. every strokes is shown on that window.

drag it to second monitor and make it fullscreen. Use any screen recording app to record the entire screen of the second monitor. I use OBS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You figure out how fast you want your "timelapse" and then record it in the right framerate.
You only capture a frame every other seconde. That little editing you might need can be done on Youtube. You don't need to render the video.
The only problem is that it will record you zooming and moving around.

nta
loose definition: 1400s-early 1800s. sometimes proto renaissance include.
conservative defnition: early renaissance, renaisssance, and baroque are core old masters. guild tradition dominant. 1700s also called old masters but not the ones people associate with old masters. academic system gains influence and dominance. artistic centers shift strongly to english and french cities. by mid 1700s painters are more aware that some qualities are lost and many try to emulate older masters. for example, there was a concern for finding the secret medium of old masters.

Well that's just filming a sexy woman dancing, then drawing over the frames you want.

Ralph Bakshi's famous for doing it cheaply. Don Bluth does it better in that you can't see the cracks as much (and that he never focussed on people)

Disney's whole animation arm was driven by this in the golden era, but they were better at hiding it. They more leant towards the reference model, rather than outright tracing like Bakshi.

I think i hit limit growth. I cant grow past around 2.2k followers (on twitter)

I post frequently and get around 600 likes on a good day but followers are going up very slowly.

Should i draw for a different audience? More original content? Or should i just try to improve my skills?

I also post comics but those don't do very well in terms of numbers despite getting lots of positive comments and stuff.

How did you guys break through the limit? Is the solution really just to keep drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

I do a lot of thumbnailing in black and white now, so I'll let the shadow shapes guide me as to what should be drawn. I was looking at a Jungle Book art book so that's where served as inspiration for this piece. I do a lot of erasing and let random paint strokes from the positive and negative shapes create new ideas, so sometimes the final image doesn't always come out as planned.

>>6437972
I don't use Twitter or anything like that, I don't even remember how I found Gloss but I do remember that I liked his art immediately.
His construction and foreshortening is rock solid, his anatomy is on point, his figures are dynamic and expressive, his composition is impactful, and his rendering looks really nice on top of all of that. Not to mention that he has a fairly broad range, stylistically. If you check out his visual novel project Sweet Canvas you'll notice that the way that he paints his characters' faces ranges from super abstracted (like Kanna, who's my favorite desu) to more defined and "realistic" (like Io, for instance). I really would have to disagree with his art being "uninspired", Gloss is SOVL as fvck.

posts.com:
This thread gave me all I needed to know about this board. It's full of people with no talent or abstractist thinking who spend years and years trying to fit into being an artist, Or Illustrator or anything. They work hard or work for a long time to become this thing they want to be however because of this they become cynical, jaded, Do they truly love it? Are they creators, Artists or just people who can draw very well.
They spend a lot of money and time on the BEST NEW equipment thinking it will make them better and it does produce a better product but at the end of the day, there are two realms when it comes to professions like these (To put it simply, Call them abstract and then traditional) and one needs to respect the other whichever they reside in
It's much like /mu/ when you post music.
Your art is awesome OP, whoever this is. The use of white is incredibily impressive . I'm always interested in art that needs to be closely looked at and when I draw, sometimes I try to draw something that is a bit "tricky" to discern what it truly is, Opening the work to multiple interpretations other than the artists.

Do Art Daily:
>Link: https://dad.gallery
>Discord: You must have a DAD streak of at least 14 to join. Ask Vastian#0988 for an invite.
>Found an issue with the site? Lost your streak and want to appeal? Please message the contact link at the bottom of the site instead of posting in the thread.

Rules:
>Draw every day (or your preferred frequency)
>Submit your work by 23:59:59 GMT
>Spend at least 30 minutes on each submission
>No loli or shota porn
>Miss a day and you'll be alright, just keep going!
>Maintain your streak and you too can become the LAST ARTIST STANDING!!
>Have fun!

Go and comment on each other's artwork; dads love attention!

FAQ:

What is the goal?
>To form a habit of drawing. The gains you make are dependent on you.

I am /beg/gar and not know draw, can I join?
>Yes x99. Stop asking and start submitting art, chum. Make something!

How long does it take until my account is approved?
>Between two to three weeks, usually when you reach level 3. Even unapproved submissions count toward your streak!

A brief history:
>Last Artist Standing (LAS): The original site, created by Lava (presumed dead, rest in peace). It has changed and ruined the lives of many lassies.
>Draw Every Day (DED): A short-lived site between LAS and DAD, run and abruptly cancelled by w.
>Do Art Daily (DAD): The current site, by the dadmin and developer banana.

Community links:
>DADcast: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCfCw_buGoBDPQC1bbcukmnQ
>LAS discord (alternative to DAD discord): https://discord.gg/5777rZnqW9

I actually love how this whole AI madness is forcing artists to strive for more, being creative and unique stuff and get as far away as possible from doing generic crap in order to not be thrown into the inevitable public scrunity.

>>6436845
This isn't a comment I got but these 2 characters I've been fleshing out for a comic for years, ended up getting "copied" by 2 big name cartoon shows like 4 years after I imagined them myself. It pissed me off at first, but I didn't let it get to me. I resolved instead to adjust my characters and their narrative world in a way that mogs those cartoons(in my opinion,) and makes my characters even more distinctly my own. I'll never get famous from it and retards might still try to compare my characters (which came first) to the characters from the cartoons, or even some unpredictable media I've never heard of. But I'll never doubt myself about it and that's what matters. My creations have a life of their own, it's my job to convince people to see them as distinct, and hell it might even be fun to lean into some of the comparisons for laughs. If you aren't fighting tooth and nail to carve out your own identity through your creations you're just too weak.

>>6439229
lol i'm a person who says this sometimes (paired with other advice). i don't say "looks like shit" because it's just not a useful citicism
it doesn't tell the other person what they did wrong or how to improve on the picture or which skill they should focus on
furthermore, it's not like putting a lot of effort into a shitty image has never happened to me - i assume the other person already knows their work looks "bad somehow" but doesn't know how to fix it, and that in that state it's pretty easy to fall into the trap of thinking all the time you put into something was a total waste and a sign that you have hit a "wall" and will never improve.
so, in combination with other suggested practical solutions, it's just a reminder that time invested into practice isn't useless, at a time when it is easy to think that way, and have that mentality block your growth.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6459784
technically, drawing on a flat surface causes the most strain on your shoulder because you have to extend your arm further out and keep your forearm at a wider angle relative to the upper arm
the only "ergonomic" desk is a an adjustable height desk desk which i recommend: i find that standing often increases my drive and reduces procrastination, but neither will really help posture(aside from cases where your chair is too far below or above the desk); if you use a monitor, you need a monitor arm that can raise the screen so it's in the center of your vision when you stand/sit straight upright, simply raising the desk will raise the working surface as well and cause shoulder pain from having to lift your arms up to reach your shit
for trad or screen tablets, you don't need a new desk to draw on a slanted surface, you can just prop up a cutting board or something on a brick or some heavy books

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6430778

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

Books:
Understanding Comics
Making Comics

The Shonen Jump Guide to Making Manga

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/
> https://writingtipsoasis.com/best-independent-comic-book-publishers/

And a new addition, not technically a publisher, but a new platform to host your manga:

Manga Plus Creators by Shueisha

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I have only looked at the chapters so I can't comment on the writing.

I really like the composition and artstyle even though it's pretty simple and scratchy.
It seems to fit the atmosphere quite well.

You should really think about using proper speechbubbles or if you want to keep the uniqe speechbubbles you currently use then please use a better font.
Your current font makes it look like those old scanlations of manga.
Lettering is just as important as art and composition.
Blambot.com has a lot of free and good looking comic fonts for dialogue and effects. Blambot even lets you use these fonts commercially for prints and stuff if you're an indie artist.

I can also see you're structuring the panels like a manga or comic page.
You don't have to do this on webtoon because of the infinite scrolling webtoons have.
Take advantage of this feature and give your panels more breathing room and space between each other.
It feels very crammed and overwhelming as it currently is. Remember, there are no pages on webtoons. There's just one very long page pretty much.
Look at how popular webtoons are placing their panels.
You can do a lot of unique and fun paneling on webtoon that you couldn't do with a traditional page-to-page layout.

Also think about using more differently shaped panels.
It's fine as it is right now but it might become boring or samey seeing the same rectangle panels as you create more chapters.


Overall it looks good and promising. Godspeed anon!

>>6454002
I read the full thing. I though it was great, main thing I dislike is the dialogue. You should change the font, have speech bubbles, and also just go over everything to remove unnecessary lines, and edit forced lines. I'm also working on a comic, and it's definitely a challenge to make dialogue seem natural and not cringe-inducing. Try and act out the interaction in your head, and ask yourself if it would be like that in a real life interaction. Also keep in the mind that the character's personality plays a role in each interaction (If you haven't done this already, you should write down a document for yourself that includes your character's personality, motivations, fears, etc..) And another thing to keep in mind is that not everything has to be vocalized.

I found it weird how this main character knows English well when she was abandoned as a little kid, I think she should be more mute (Or maybe you could make her dialogue have a purposefully limited choice of words.) And like the other anon said, it should be explained how she built an entire house by herself, knows how to cook, and how she has money.

Overall I thought this was pretty cool and I'm looking forward to your revisions and more chapters.

>asymmetrical and you want to show it from both sides.
Yup that's one of my problems alright, and I also feel like an idiot when I do the magic side flip. That pic says it all.
My particular design isn't completely unrealistic so it is by all means possible to convincingly draw it from all angles, but it's not only time consuming but just a touch beyond my skill set. I'm really studying the shape of skulls and the way locks of hair grow out of them, but then I also have to convert that to stylized shapes that suit my chosen style. Figure out what liberties I should take with shape placement at awkward angles so it doesn't look goofy. And then I'll have to be consistent with it every goddamn time. Bodies and clothing inconsistencies can be forgiven but when a characters head looks off, everyone can immediately tell something is off. I'm always amazed how mangaka keep their art so crisp for 10+ years at a time.

posts.com:
I bang my head against a brick wall I first encountered when I was six years old, and never make even the slightest progress towards getting past it. I read books and perform exercises they reccomend, but completely fail to understand what I'm supposed to gain from them or what they have to do with actually drawing something. I constantly revise my theories and definitions regarding things like drawing, contours, sketching, perspective, and lines as a medium, which never manifests into anything I can actually apply to my work. I use the same flawed process over and over again while hoping for different results because I can't even think of any alternatives to experiment with. I try to reverse-engineer literal childrens' doodles in the hopes of figuring out what thought process could have led to their creation, and come up with nothing. I focus almost entirely on the aspects of drawing I don't enjoy or care about becuase they at least make some degree of sense, whereas the things I might actually have fun with are so alien and incomprehensible that I can't figure out how to engage with them at all.

My drawing journey isn't going very well. Don't be like me.

In my experience, everyone learns differently, which is why it's so hard to give good advice. Also, most artists who've "made it" couldn't tell you exactly how they got there, in perfect sequence, because it tends to be haphazard, with a lot of trial and error. Certain information only helps when you're ready for it, so in two years you might return to something that seems useless now only to have it trigger an epiphany. You can definitely learn observational drawing by following a prescribed method (join an atelier program for the fastest and most assured progress), but there's no fail-proof guide to drawing from imagination and developing an appealing style.

That wasn't me replying lol.

The longer you draw, the better is your visual library (images and concepts stored in your memory) and at some point you can do basically anything from memory, At least when it comes to the human figure. I've been at it form more than 20 years.

Was thinking about this just this morning. AI is definitely a wakeup call but certainly not the death of the artist. It has its place and use as a tool of convenience.

I think we'll have to adapt in much the same way that AI does. Specifically, by rejecting digital mediums for the physical, relearning traditional techniques, and developing a unique style after figuring out some fundies. Many art communities online are having absolute meltdowns because they can't tell the difference between an AI piece and an original work even though the funny shit is the vast majority of people online are using digital and tablets. There's a very simple workaround for this: make your art physically. Sure some pajeet can make a robot that can emulate skill, but no pajeet will replace the human soul. Trads don't have to give a shit, just post timestamp.

Personally, digital artwork lacks a lot of appeal in the first place. Not to say it isn't or can't be good, I just think it's missing something fundamental to the human soul that goes into it. The mistakes are too easily corrected, the physicality of touching paper, oils, color, spilling shit and just getting weird with it are gone. Spill coffee on your computer and you could lose a keyboard, spill coffee on a canvas and it can be inspiring. AI gives me the feeling people are seeing with their eyes whether or not a piece has appeal, and not their heart. Some of the dumbest shit speaks to me even if it's not some high ideal, but so far, AI hasn't. It simply doesn't have a human soul to connect with.

I'm predicting a renaissance of physical, traditional, and certainly original art soon as a natural counter to AI and looking forward to it. We'll end up with a lot of weird growing pains but I truly think it'll pay off. Once you can show something was made with your own hands, there can be no further doubt to authenticity. Mark my words, in the coming years a selling point to media will be a "all human art team."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6459252
YES. It's ultimately about why. Ego stroking is easy; show your shit to someone that doesn't know shit and the compliments will come. It comes down to care and love. My work ain't great and using reference I make a highly inefficient photocopier, but when I make something like that it's because I genuinely care about what I'm doing enough to put time, energy and love into it. And it affirms itself in how I'm treated by those I give that energy to, because if they're worth their salt as a human being and companion, they recognize that.

For example, I put a lot of effort into a piece to give as a going away/Christmas present to my bro. I worked on reference, but eyeballed it and put serious care into a real physical work I feel confident could be framed and put up for display. I got dirty, spilled a bunch of stuff, my back hurt from standing for hours, drank and smoked too much. He's no artist and wouldn't know what goes into the process, but he's my fucking friend and I wanted to show appreciation for his companionship.

Now imagine if someone put some keywords into a robot about some shit of interest to someone, printed out the result and said "I made this for you." It's like going to Walmart and sending a postcard from the stationary aisle. It's boring low effort stuff and maybe you'd be better off using it as packing material.

It's about why you do it and what you want to say, not about what you see.

The idea for these ships is that the hull structure is built mainly AROUND the balloon instead of just on top or underneath, the balloons would obviously be filled with a special type of gas that isn't helium.

>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

I'd say anon is partially right, while the mining isn't a good industry to work at, the technolgy that was brought into it has increased the efficiency of a worker, but most importantly safety. Before there were advanced supports, ventillation technology, ways to detect harmful gasses, being miner was way more lethal and in general dangerous. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6453196
Well anon for a real answer it has a lot of qualities that are attractive and at least worth talking about.

Balance, contrast, rhythm, focal points. These things exist in most representational art, but here they exist kind of by themselves, deconstructed.

Lines, curves, shapes in representational drawing are tools, means to an end. Here they are the subject, the focus.

You can see how in some spots, even two lines create the suggestion of 3d space, not any real space mind you, but a sort of abstraction of 3d space itself.

You can see how colored shapes interact almost like they are transparent stained glass. Not necessarily following the actual color theory rules of how they'd interact, but still reading as color interactions of that sort.

It's like molecular/deconstructed cuisine. A way of treating the ingredients in a different way, of letting them take a life of their own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: isn't Blind Contour drawing literally able to be replaced by tracing art using a screenless tablet??

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458632
No, because blind contour gives you no visual feedback as to what you're drawing. You can see where your cursor is if you trace using a tablet, so you can correct. I guess it's marginally harder than just tracing on paper, but it really doesn't train the same visual skill and concentration ability as blind contour drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458640
isn't the ability to correct in realtime better than just guessing the whole time?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458661
Yeah, if you're working on a piece. Blind contour is meant to get you in a certain mindset and train you to focus your eye and brain on what you're seeing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You're still young. 22 is still in the "your entire life ahead of you" zone.

Having drawn a lot as a kid obviously helps, but if you just want to draw well, you can achieve that quite feasibly over the course of a few years. While obviously you have your cases of prodigies and savants or whatever, we're not dealing with the extraordinary here. Most kids that spend a ton of time drawing don't know how to pick up skills and at best just develop a few healthy habits, making their growth relatively negligible compared to a couple of years of thoughtful study and application.

Cut yourself some slack and get to work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6457963
my talent in writing helped me to understand the skill of drawing a little better

since i was in middle school, teachers would always compliment my ability to write yet i never actually did anything towards this ability and never "worked hard" to attain the ability i have

i always find it insulting whenever i see artists on here imply that they "worked hard" for their ability when in reality they were always inclined towards that activity
i never felt like i "worked hard" for my writing ability yet teachers were pulling me aside and telling me how great my writing is

artists on here implying that "talent" does not play a major role are simply being misleading and causing those people who wish to pursue drawing as a skill a disservice by purposely providing a disingenuous aspect to the act of drawing

the definition of talent is being able to be good at something without being taught which does not imply that you can draw nothing and be good but rather it is implying that someone with talent in drawing can attain a high level of skill by literally just drawing, hence the meme: "just draw"

i saw this in my own ability as i, having not received former training, never having once watched a single youtube video or training video about writing, and never having read a single book on how to write well, have seen massive improvements in my ability to write by simply writing which was a very interesting phenomenon

when i tried to carry this towards drawing, the results were lackluster, to say the least
it was as if "justdrawing" seemed to do nothing for me
the more i drew, the worst it seemed like i became
i never improved even after years of drawings and was forced to actually learn how to draw through instructional videos and the like
this was very strange to me considering i never had to do this with writing

that is when i realized that this thing that i had for writing was what people called talent, i wasn't born with it but i had a natural ability for it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428274
Just got this, extremely disappointing compared to the color & light book.
I feel like color & light offered a well rounded balance of theory, technical information and examples that other books lack and is exhaustive.

The composition and narrative book is a by-the-numbers text dump of golden ratio, rule of thirds, dark foreground, light background type stuff and offers no examples from Greg Rutkowski himself via thumbnails/sketches or other studies to show practical examples.

Framed Ink 1 & 2, Creative Illustration by Loomis and Edgar Paynes composition of outdoor painting all offer much more.

3DTotal back to their usual low quality books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435278
You can learn anatomy in med school, but you still won't be able to draw it well. Figure drawing is learning to draw the figure. Learning anatomy is purelly informational knowledge. It does help you understand what you are trying to represent, or when drawing from imagination to know where to position things, but it isn't drawing information. Most pepole say you should start with figure drawing, when you feel confortable with it but you feel you are being held back by not knowing the specifics of the muscles and body parts, then you go to anatomy.

anon, i've gone through a thousand (literally) artbooks and his books are LITERALLY the only ones that a beginner can actually use

Hello frens, I come here today to share a script I worked on to automate the machine translation of books for the community. I tried to make it as retard-proof as I possibly could so that even the most intellectually challenged of us could use it with no issues.

The instructions are on the gcolab page, but just to be sure I'll list here the steps involved:
>obtain the book you want to translate
>compress it as a zip of images (no folder)
>upload that zip to your gdrive
>read the instructions carefully and run the script
>optional: upscale the images, makes the book much heavier but better quality
>optional: you can translate more than one book if you use various accounts
>obs: "disconnect and delete runtime" to run the script again after you finish translating a book
>obs: I recommend using sumatrapdf on windows for reading books

Link: https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1iDUOHzY734o_UTvurasbVxm75rUY0Tpq?usp=sharing

Proof of concept:

>*upscaled* japanese book on drawing hair
https://mega.nz/file/MgxSHZgZ#XMqt66g08gcVSBlCGgYt-DQ8_ZYU4faw_HQDA-SYU4A

>*not upscaled* hitokaku
https://mega.nz/file/Z0hkUJZS#FkZ-fBqpWfD-EJhW6YMqgFfiRMRUeBDGmg-MHpq3_Sc

>I won't be doing maintenance on this script, so I suggest translating the books you want sooner rather than later.
>Also for any anons that code, feel free to improve the script.

>>>>Roxy, the Goddess of Wisdom<<<<

>>6451772
Books and poetry are indeed art. Prompts are not. Prompts are more fundamental. The same prompt might generate many types of arts.

It's like I wanted to copyright blue + yellow color combination. Many arts can be made with those 2 colors. Same with music. You're free to pick any scale and any of the notes to create your art with any instrument. Just because you use 3 chords from the available pool of options, does not give you rights to the chords itself.

You can make a point of owning the final art of a prompt, the ones you generate with it. But the prompt itself is not art, it does not matter how complex it is. It is a tool that anyone can use, and it can generate art for them that are different from yours.

>>6456847
lol. Except that -unlike when choosing a partner- when drawing you actually need to be careful with anatomical features, since you're the one creating them.

Pointy elbows and knees in drawing (when not a part of a style that makes use of pointy shapes) is an easy way to tell the artist has little anatomical background. The olecranon process of the ulna is rounded, and connects directly to the tendon of the triceps; making it roundish. The kneecap is surrounded by tendons from the quads, and the condyles of the femur and the top of the tibia are also part of what you see when a knee is bent.

In other words... you need to study

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456780
>Yes, passion, soul and spirit are just made up concepts to try to attack AI art because it so obviously looks good to the human eye.
There's more to art than just looking good to the human eye. That's why the term "eye candy" is derogatory in art, it means superficial.
'Soul' deconstructed is simply the human element. The more the human element is taken out of art, the less 'soul' it has. It's why jazz and blues has more soul than the latest auto-tuned pop song. It's why Ray Harryhausen's stop motion has more soul than shitty CGI effects. It's why great literature has more soul than formulaic YA novels.
Substance is another way to look at. And apple might be shiny but have nothing inside.

From my old notes:

In 2014, a study found that walking increased creativity.[13]

Some advocate enhancing creativity by taking advantage of hypnagogia, the transition from wakefulness to sleep, using techniques such as lucid dreaming. One technique used by Salvador Dalí was to drift off to sleep in an armchair with a set of keys in his hand; when he fell completely asleep, the keys would fall and wake him up, allowing him to recall his mind's subconscious imaginings.[14] Thomas Edison used the same technique, with ball bearings.[15]

A study[16] from 2014 conducted by researchers in China and the US, including the psychologist Michael Posner found that performing a short 30 minute meditation session each day, for seven days, was sufficient to improve verbal and visual creativity, as measured by the Torrance Tests of Creative Thinking, due to the positive effects of meditation on emotional regulation. The same researchers[17] also showed in 2015 that short term meditation training could also improve insight-based problem solving (the type commonly associated with an "Ah-ha", or "eureka" type moment of realization) as measured by the Remote Associates Test.

It's about figuring out what you want to say, what kind of artwork brings you enjoyment. Self-discovery. Some people are slower on the uptake for this kind of thing. Don't be afraid of trial and error; throw together different concepts/themes that don't seem like they'll work, and try to make it work. This is the backbone of creativity. When you have no principles guiding you it's all you have. If you stay safe and don't experiment you will not grow artistically.

posts.com:
>>6455834
This style is both simple and difficult. Simple because it is black and white and a little flat color one can reproduce this even in real life with one single black ink pen. But difficult because you only got black line so you need to rely on solids and hatching to create midtones which both takes work and you need to be able to judge the form well to know where to put those midtones without making it look off. You also need to play a lot with rim lights to make the form edges come out well.

Do you have some more specific questions? This looks pretty much the standard comic style.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6455788
1. Copy a bunch of the drawings from it to get used to the shapes and line quality.
2. Modify and redraw parts of it yourself (give a character a new hairstyle, different facial expressions, a new pose) while trying to keep the style.
3. Put it all together - draw your own characters in that style and, literally, copy and paste them into the comic to see if it looks accurate on those backgrounds or next to other characters.

>>6457107
An okay start, draw him/her more, a lot more. Different poses and situations, this will help flesh out the whos and whats of a character as you keep iterating on him changed the black/white colors make him wear clothes, give him items or features like instead of mouse teeth give him a grin or fang or a mask etc etc.. What is he like? What does he do? What is his role in the story you are telling etc. And do not stop there think about what other characters he would meet, how would they look do they have cohesion? and so on

Keep doing it and I am sure you will find the answers yourself. Here are some exampled on how I would have made him based on your sketch.
